name: James M. Inhofe
content:
As you and your families enjoy a long weekend, I hope you will join me in reflection and gratitude for America’s greatest heroes: our service members who made the ultimate sacrifice.

When I get a chance to meet with our troops, it underscores everything we ask them to do to defend our nation and the values we hold dear. I see them making sacrifices of time spent with their own families, the stress of frequent moves and uncertainty about what the future holds, and the risks they take each and every day, especially when they are overseas.

We can never say thank you enough.

name: Bill Johnson
content:
As I was doing my personal devotions this past week, I happened upon a passage from Psalm’s that comforted me. I pray it comforts you as well.

Psalm 119:81-82 -“I am worn out waiting for your rescue, but I have put my hope in your word. My eyes are straining to see your promises come true. When will you comfort me?”

Then, later in Psalms 119 we find...

Psalm 119:89-94a...”Your eternal word, O Lord, stands firm in heaven. Your faithfulness extends to every generation, as enduring as the earth you created. Your regulations remain true to this day, for EVERYTHING serves your plans. If your instructions hadn’t sustained me with joy, I would have died in my misery. I will never forget your commandments, for by them you give me life. I am yours, rescue me!”

The message I heard that applies to me is that I should put into action the following passage...

1 Thessalonians 5:16-18...”Rejoice always, pray continually, give thanks in all circumstances, for this is God’s will for you in Christ Jesus.”

Things don’t always work out the way we want or the way we plan. But, we should remember daily that ONLY he can change our circumstances. Rather than get frustrated, we should live our lives in obedience to his directions, take our petitions to him in prayer, and be joyful where we are - being assured that he is listening.

And as we face uncertain times in our lives, we should realize that... “God is trying to teach us something, and the best thing we can do is to LEARN QUICKLY.”

Have a blessed day, dear friends. 😊🙏🏻🇺🇸

name: James M. Inhofe
content: Today, we mark 100 years since the Tulsa Massacre. Before 1921, Greenwood district, also known as Black Wall Street, was a vibrant, thriving prosperous Black community. But then, the evening of May 31 into the early morning of June 1, 1921—there was a horrific massacre where hundreds of Black Tulsans were murdered and thousands were made homeless overnight. It was truly terrible and horrific. That’s why it is important to come together to honor the victims and their families and share their stories today and with future generations. Together, we can all work to lift up the story of Black Wall Street and use this anniversary to remember, reflect and work—as we do every day—towards reconciliation.

name: Adam B. Schiff
content:
Today, we gather across America to express our gratitude for the brave men and women of our armed forces and their families.

Those who serve our country in uniform are the best of us, and today we pause to remember those who made the ultimate sacrifice so that we may all live our freest and fullest lives. They gave up everything they had, and everything they would ever have - their jobs, their families, their futures - so that we could live free and enjoy the blessings of this great country.

This Memorial Day, I'm thinking in particular about those constituents who I met while visiting our troops in Afghanistan and Iraq. Of their families, and of those who perished in the service of our country. And I'm thinking of those who came before them, who fought and died on foreign battlefields all over the world, and the extraordinary nature of their courage and sacrifice. We owe them so very much.

Thank you to all who are gathering today and to all who have served this nation in uniform. We salute you, and God bless you.
text: today gather across america express gratitude brave men women armed forces familiesthose serve country uniform best us today pause remember made ultimate sacrifice may live freest fullest lives gave everything everything would ever jobs families futures could live free enjoy blessings great countrythis memorial day im thinking particular constituents met visiting troops afghanistan iraq families perished service country im thinking came fought died foreign battlefields world extraordinary nature courage sacrifice owe muchthank gathering today served nation uniform salute god bless

name: James M. Inhofe
content:
One month isn't enough to say thank you to our troops their service and sacrifice. This #MilitaryAppreciationMonth, we have to show our troops we care - by giving them the budgetary resources they deserve.

Taking care of our troops — giving them the pay, housing, family support, health care, equipment and weapons, and training they deserve — that’s at least a third of our defense budget right there. That’s the right thing to do — our service members are the backbone of our national security, and they're all volunteers, every single one.

Our troops lay everything on the line to defend our nation. They sacrifice time with their families and friends. As we remember each year on #MemorialDay, many make the ultimate sacrifice.

There aren’t enough words to express our gratitude. That’s why we have to show them.

name: James Lankford
content:
Today our state will honor and recognize the lives lost, the survivors, and the continued growth of Greenwood on the 100th anniversary of the Tulsa Race Massacre. Oklahomans want the nation to know the accurate history of events 100 years ago, the growing economic development in the Greenwood District, and the continued work toward reconciliation. The importance of this work will grow after the anniversary, and I look forward to continuing to walk with my many friends in Greenwood as well as tell the story of tragedy to triumph.

name: Gregory F. Murphy
content:
Today on Memorial Day we remember the American men and women who have laid down their lives so we can enjoy peace and freedom. We are so blessed to live in a country that was founded on principles that are worth fighting for such as democracy, freedom, justice and equality. The service and sacrifice demonstrated by American service members in defense of these national pillars of our country is humbling and will forever be appreciated.

In particular, eastern North Carolinians should keep fallen military members from Camp Lejeune, Marine Corps Air Stations New River and Cherry Point and Coast Guard Base Elizabeth City in our thoughts and prayers today. Their immeasurable sacrifices will never be forgotten, and the void left by their tragic passing can never be filled. We are so fortunate to have such a heavy Marine Corps and Coast Guard presence in the Third District. May God bless our troops and God bless America!

name: Bill Johnson
content:
Salmon Chase, a New Hampshirite by birth but an Ohioan by choice, is this week’s person of interest. His law career began in Cincinnati, where he fought for the rights of those trapped in slavery. As he rose in prominence, he went on to serve Ohio as a U.S. Senator and Governor.

When President Lincoln came into office in 1861, he needed serious help raising the money to replenish the federal coffer…for he had almost no money with which to build his administration and raise an army to fight off the drumbeats of war already being heard in the distance. So, President Lincoln appointed Chase as Secretary of Treasury and later as Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court. His deep commitment to end slavery and fight for democracy never waivered throughout his distinguished life of service. His efforts, along with the efforts of other great Ohioans during that era, made our nation a more free, decent, and prosperous nation.

name: Bill Johnson
content:
Since the Revolutionary War, the American solider has served as the guardian at the gate of freedom and the protector of the values we hold dear. The first Memorial Day (then called Decoration Day) was celebrated shortly after the Civil War ended. On May 5, 1868, General John Logan, national commander of the Grand Army of the Republic, promulgated General Order No. 11, which officially established Memorial Day.

In 1923, shortly before he ascended to the presidency, then Vice-President Calvin Coolidge stressed the importance of American ideals and the sacrifices needed to protect them in a speech titled "The Destiny of America". In that speech, he paid tribute to America's fallen heroes and Memorial Day, explaining that we set the day apart "to do honor to all those, now gone, who made the cause of America their supreme choice." Coolidge also quoted John 15:13: "Greater love hath no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends."

So, as we observe this Memorial Day, please join me in remembering and honoring those who made the ultimate sacrifice in defense of the United States. Our fallen heroes have come from various backgrounds, races, religions, and areas of the country, but they all believed in America and laid down their lives in her defense. Every American is in their debt.

name: Lisa Murkowski
content: It was an honor to join the 33rd Annual Memorial Day ceremony at Byers lake—a tradition that has always been close to my heart. For countless families across the nation, Memorial Day is a stark and often painful reminder of those who were never afforded the opportunity to be honored as veterans for their service to our country. Their sacrifice is a true expression of selfless service—they represent the best America has to offer. Thank you to the Alaska Veterans Motorcycle Club for not only what you do at this event year after year, but also what you do each and every day in your communities. We are richer as a state because of the role that you play.

On #MemorialDay, we reflect on the generations of Americans who selflessly gave their lives for our nation. These men & women paid the ultimate sacrifice so all of us can enjoy the freedoms we cherish. Mere words will never be enough to honor what they have given to our nation.

Today, I join all New Mexicans, and all Americans, in remembering our fallen heroes, recognizing all the veterans who served our nation, and honoring those who continue to serve today at home and abroad.

name: Lisa Murkowski
content: Today, on Memorial Day, we pay tribute, honor, and respect to those Americans who have given their last full measure to our country. Over the past 75 years we have lost brave Alaskans in wars and battles throughout the world and we know there are many who called our great state home who also paid the ultimate sacrifice. Whether they are fallen servicemembers from Alaska or places throughout America we honor them for their sacrifice and for serving our country so admirably. It is said that heroes never really die, as long as we continue to remember and pay tribute to their legacy. It’s up to each of us to make sure they are never forgotten. Let’s join together in a commitment to honor Americas bravest, today and every day—through our words and actions—keeping their memory and honor alive. God Bless.

name: Donald M. Payne, Jr.
content: This is a great day for the commuters in New Jersey, New York and across the Northeast Corridor. After years of obstruction by the previous administration, the Hudson River Tunnel is one step closer to full approval. This project will help reduce rail congestion and allow thousands of commuters to get to their final destinations faster. It will provide desperately needed new infrastructure and ensure the reliability and efficiency of travel throughout the area. When I met with President Biden and spoke with Transportation Secretary Buttigieg, they said the Gateway Program was a priority for this administration and they have proven it. I look forward to working with this administration to get the funding necessary to construct this critical infrastructure project -Rep Donald M. Payne, Jr.

name: Paul A. Gosar
content:
Sneak peak into our round table discussion on mining in Arizona with mining industry representatives and state and local leaders.

Did you know solar panels, wind turbines and electric vehicles ALL require critical minerals derived from mining?

We can’t discuss clean energy if we don’t first acknowledge that it doesn’t happen without mining.

If we don’t mine here, these minerals are often obtained using slave labor with terrible environmental standards in other parts of the world.

It’s time to mine again in the U.S. ⛏

name: David P. Joyce
content:
While many folks enjoy cookouts and time spent with friends and family this weekend, we must never forget what Memorial Day is truly about.

Begun in the years following the Civil War, this holiday is meant to remember our fallen heroes, to honor the men and women who were called to defend our God-given right to freedom. It’s only right to give thanks to the soldiers who laid down their lives so that we may live ours freely in the greatest nation the world has ever known. We owe them, and their families, our infinite gratitude. 🇺🇸

On this day and every day, we must stand up for the values that they so valiantly fought for.

On Wednesday, June 23, 2021, from 3:00PM-7:00PM ET (Thursday, June 24, 2021, 5:00AM-9:00AM Chamorro Standard Time), the State Health Insurance Assistance Programs (SHIP) National Technical Assistance Center, in partnership with the Administration for Community Living, will host a Welcome to Medicare National Virtual Fair for new Medicare enrollees – people turning 65, retiring, or joining Medicare because of a disability.

name: Donald M. Payne, Jr.
content: Today is World No Tobacco Day. This day was created by the Member States of the World Health Organization in 1987 as a response to the global tobacco crisis, the diseases and deaths caused by the epidemic. It is commemorated each year on May 31st to raise awareness of the harmful effects of tobacco use and second-hand smoke and to discourage use of tobacco in any form. The World No Tobacco Day theme for 2021 is #CommittoQuit.

name: Theodore E. Deutch
content:
Have you felt stressed or down during the last year due to the pandemic? You are not alone. The COVID-19 pandemic and dramatic changes to our daily lives have taken a major toll on Americans throughout the past year. As May is Mental Health Awareness Month, it is important to remember that you are alone in this fight.

According to the National Alliance on Mental Health, nearly 1 in 5 Floridians will experience a mental illness each year. That is why investing in the mental health of our community is so critical. In order to have healthier communities, we must address the disparities in critical mental health resources and work to end the stigma associated with mental health.

If you are in a crisis, please know that you are not alone.

Suicide Prevention:
National Hotline- 800-273-8255
Veterans Crisis Line- Call 1-800-273-8255 or Text 838255

General Sources:
https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/daily-life-coping/managing-stress-anxiety.html
https://www.mentalhealth.va.gov

MENTALHEALTH.VA.GOV
VA.gov | Veterans Affairs
